content.body: Hixie: ping
annevk2: <hr> and <input> has never been done through XBL
well, <input> was as an experiment that never shipped
Lachy: are you about?
does anyone know what the deal is with http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" in HTML5? not allowed b/c versioning? jury is out? other?
if anyone had "2.5 hours" in the "how long will it take john foliot to lose his shit after we start discussing summary" pool, you're a winner!
I have reminded John that he signed off on the current draft text and encouraged him to dial down his rhetoric accordingly
boblet: it's redundant, since all versions of browsers are required to act the same way. :-)
Hixie: heh, nice. Thanks for the answer
blinks at jf's e-mail
i thought what the spec said today was in fact jf's idea
it's certainly not what i want the spec to say
Hixie: about r3852, if <span title=&> is now not a parse error, then title=&&> and ...title=&&&>, etc., are not either, right?
title=&& never was, as far as i know, and title=&&> was only because of the >, which is now no longer an error case (never was, according to the syntax section)
OK
Philip`: regarding your email to rdf-in-xhtml-tf, I find it more disappointing that parties other than Google claimed that Google implements RDFa
hsivonen: patch - http://bugzilla.validator.nu/attachment.cgi?id=115
for http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=653
seems like a dead-simple change, but just want to make sure I didn't miss anything elsewhere
MikeSmith: looks good
hsivonen: what do you think of the PFWG idea of issuing a validator warning every time a <table> element is used (effectively)?

othermaciej: I think it doesn't make sense to issue a warning on every table especially if the PFWG position is along the lines that summary isn't always necessary but the feature must remain for use when the table is confusing enough to need it

othermaciej: as an aside, I haven't fully reviewed the proposed text yet, but I noticed that one of the sample summaries contains data that any screen reader that doesn't suck should be able to voice from the table model given headers marked up as <th>
suggesting that authors include such text because AT vendors don't get their act together seems to get Priority of Constituencies the wrong way
hsivonen: Cynthia's comments about autogenerated summary seem to be related
hsivonen: Those people didn't have any way to verify Google's claims (until now), so it doesn't seem unreasonable for them to have assumed Google did something sane
Philip`: maybe my default assumption in the absence of evidence to contrary was correct but more cynical than other people's
it seems to me that if we want to consider autogenerated summary, it's much better for the UA/AT side to generate it, than the authoring tool side
othermaciej: indeed
hsivonen: anyway - would be good to have some level-headed mailing list feedback on this once you have reviewed the proposal enough
othermaciej: ok

Philip`: note that I don't mean to disparage Google in any way. That's just my default assumption about *any* even vaguely Namespace-related software--that I assume it's not correct until shown correct

hsivonen: It seems reasonable to assume they'll have a few bugs, but it also seems reasonable to assume they'll have at least attempted to do something basically correct and not just totally ignored the whole specification
Philip`: fair enough
Philip`: indeed, I didn't expect the deviation from the spec to be as great as you have shown
It seems kind of like whoever designed Google's RDFa support just read the RDFa Primer and didn't bother with the proper spec or with understanding RDF or namespaces at all
so they implemented RegexpDFa?
Philip`: it's also possible that whoever designed it understood it and deemed the specced approach too complex
doesn't mean to be personally offensive to whoever designed or implemented it, but maybe he does because it seems pretty rubbish :-p
hsivonen: Too complex to implement, or too complex to author?
the nested types bug is surprising
er, nested properties
Philip`: to author, because I'd assume Google can get software implemented

othermaciej: Doesn't seem too surprising giving that they seemingly don't support @datatype, and in the absence of @datatype RDFa says you shouldn't recurse into property elements (they should just be treated as XMLLiterals instead)
Philip`: I see
Philip`: whoa! does RDFa default to XMLLiterals as opposed to plain strings for property values?
(You have to use datatype="" to stop that XMLLiteral behaviour)
interesting!
hsivonen: Yes, though I think they're thinking of changing that in RDFa 1.1
(Well, it defaults to XMLLiterals if there are any element children - if it's just text then it's an untyped string literal)
(I guess this reveals that I've never taken the time to be exhaustive in review of RDFa)
(I've stopped at earlier issues)
Philip`: ok. that's reasonable in a way

hsivonen: If they wanted to make it easier to author, it seems there would be far better ways of doing that in a way that's still largely compatible with RDFa, e.g. do all the proper CURIE processing but then have a special hack for values with an undeclared prefix "v" or something
Philip`: good point
What's the longest it should take for a message to reach a W3C list (if the author's never posted before and it does the slow authorisation stuff)?
why does the spec suggest a weird Mood–Grade table?
wouldn't the best way of making it accessible be making it non-weird?
is rather surprised to find the Mood–Grade in the main spec
what's Mood-Grade?
othermaciej: see http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-table-element
othermaciej: search string "For instance, the following table:"
hsivonen: I think Hixie wanted a short but odd table
I agree it sucks though
that is a weird table
has trouble locating validator-sensitive text in the draft Cynthia posted
is disappointed but not too surprised that PFWG have retreated away from the compromise in the spec to something rather close to their originl position
hsivonen: i needed a table that had table headers in the middle or that was otherwise not something that a brief scan of the table would show to be a simple table to understand
hsivonen: http://dev.w3.org/html5/pf-summary/Overview.html#guidance-for-conformance-checkers-0
hsivonen: if you have any better suggestions for a table that really needs summary, let me know
othermaciej: ooh. Thanks.
what are the existing extensibility mechanisms in HTML5? ones I can think of: class, rel, meta, XML namespaces in XML syntax, data- attributes, "other applicable specifications" clause
did I miss any?
microdata?
othermaciej: the faq has a whole bunch of them
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FAQ#HTML5_should_support_a_way_for_anyone_to_invent_new_elements.21
jgraham_: duh!
Hixie: thanks
mulls over <script type="">, plugins, and extending APIs via JavaScript
thought that script libraries altering prototypes was considered bad form
I think I will stick to markup-level extensibility in what I'm writing for the most part
roc, I meant the <hr> and <input> that are displayed when you use <isindex>
wasn't there a third registry besides meta and rel extensions?
othermaciej: do you have an opinion on the idea of allowing reverse-DNS identifiers in element name as an extension mechanism?
othermaciej: http-equiv
hsivonen: mixed feelings
hsivonen: on the plus side... something that's clearly a prefix-based convention is likely be better than using XML-style namespaces

hsivonen: on the minus side... (a) reverse-DNS might be needlessly verbose compared to a registry system for prefixes; and (b) any system that decorates the name would be tempting to use for proprietary UA extensions but is totally unsuitable for such
(I say (b) because if a UA extension with a prefixey name becomes popular, then the spec may have to enshrine it with the funny name, thus violating the sanctity of the namespacing mechanism)
<com.netscape.blink>, <com.microsoft.marquee>
othermaciej: true, <com.apple.canvas> would have sucked big time
com.netscape.table
com.netscape.img
actually com.mcom.img
that's different from CSS properties or APIs with a prefix, where it's somewhat practical to consider the possibility of multiple names
that might even be true for markup attributes
Hixie: were those purely unilateral or were there drafts for those under discussion at the time?
but not really for tag names
hsivonen: img was unilateral, pretty sure table was too
Hixie: I thought <table> had a I-D going for it
maybe
<com.netscape.embed>
<com.netscape.keygen>
Hixie: microdata and Namespaces have the same problem
anything that bakes a domain name in the identifier does
microdata's naming problem isn't set in stone yet and i doubt we'll use what's in the spec now
not sure what we'll use
btw, using reverse dns tag names for extending the vocabulary for small-scale use (the usual reason people want this) is even worse than the browser unilateral extensions
because it means you have no fallback for non-supporting UAs
which is why class="" and data-*="" are the right solution
but i've said this lots of times already
maybe we should have an ext attribute that is like class except it's new so it's better
we could call it role=""!
doesn't see how fallback is related to the use of reverse dns
it's not
any mechanism that affects the tag name part is equally bad
the point is that <cite class="book"> is better than <ext:book> or <com.example.book> (or <book> before being in a spec)
Oh, I thought you were saying it was bad in microdata for some reason
oh no the fallback issue is unrelated to the microdata issue
the microdata issue is that we want to have property names that are short, but want to allow vocabulary mixing
Hixie: btw, what's happing with the viewport meta state? If both iPhone and Fennec support it, it's a bit pointless to pretend it's not conforming
which basically means requiring a registry for each vocabulary
hsivonen: i guess someone should add it to the registry
does Fennec do the same thing with it that iPhone does?
(I'm not actually sure offhand what MobileSafari does with it)
othermaciej: I'm not sure. I just assumed the idea is to do the right thing with content that's already authored with awareness of MobileSafari
i think safari uses it to define the dimensions of the ICB or something like that
The fallback thing indicates a need to lets documents declare subclass relationships between elements
or to define the dimensions of the viewport, and then it uses something that isn't the viewport to render the page or something like that
Philip`: we could use RDF for that
Philip`: we could use an attribute called "class" to indicate that
Philip`: Using RDF boondoggles perhaps?
e.g. use @profile to point to a thing that says com.example.book is a subclass of cite
ok, i was being serious, i dunno about you three
and once that extensibility mechanism is deployed, it'll be much easier to extend the language
is always serious
right, MobileSafari's zooming/panning is modeled as something other than scrolling, and thus it does not affect the CSS viewport
huh
notices lots of emails with the word "summary" in his inbox
Jeremy suggsts using <details> <dt> ... <dd> ... </details> instead of <details> <legend> ... </legend> ... </details>
that's not a bad idea
it's an intriguing idea
big plus: avoids the <legend> parsing issue without adding elements
yeah
and gives you a separate container for the contents of <details> making styling easier
I was thinking the <dd> seems unnecessary, but that's a good point about styling
what about applying the pattern to <figure>, too?
then we'd have to rename <figure> to start with "d"
<diagram>?
digure
i really don't see why y'all are so worried about either <details> or <figure>, to be honest
othermaciej: I don't think it follows that figure needs renaming
Hixie, I was somewhat convinced with the argument that if authors cannot use it for the next decade because of IE it's not really better than XHTML 2.0
though not entirely
Hixie: I don't think waiting a decade for them to be usable is a good tradeoff for avoiding creation of new elements
Hixie: I think you should take the worry as demand data just like popular class names.
Hixie: also, what annevk2 said about XHTML2 applies
Hixie: it's even more not a good tradeoff for using one existing element with a somewhat semantically appropriate name vs. another with a slightly less on-point name
i guess i don't understand the demand
i mean, sure, they're neat and all
but they don't add much
Presumably the features exist in the spec because people want to use them, and so it's not surprising that people are unhappy when they find they can't use them
especially since <caption> and <label> are arguably both more semantically appropriate than <legend> but can't be used due to technical difficulties
Hixie: everyone who has had to develop containers for a floating img+caption pair wants a <figure> they can use yesterday
the Cocoa equivalent of <details> is used all over Mac OS X UI
it's a great component for a UI toolbox

I liked the idea of using <details> with <dt> and <dd>, though I'm also concerned about the compatibility issues that would be caused if authors started using it now before browser implementations are ready
it would be hard for script to make one as polished as a native implementation
if <details> didn't use <legend> it would get some native browser implementations a lot sooner
othermaciej: why?
Lachy: yeah, that's actually an argument for keeping <legend>, as far as i can tell
Hixie: is the "why?" regarding my last statement?
yeah
seems like fixing the <legend> bugs is easy
at least compared to the magic involved in <details>
maybe not for <figure>
for Safari/WebKit development, we prioritize implementing features that Web developers can actually use, preferably before IE6 disappears from the market
the functionality provided though, such as the hiding/showing, and the rendering of +/- expander controls could interfere with sites using it before implementations ship
othermaciej: they won't be able to use <details> before then anyway
maybe making V.nu whine about <details> would be better than using <legend>
so it's basically not on our roadmap right now until the <legend> landscape changes (though we do intend to do something about <legend> parsing soonish)
Hixie: unless they do some script-based fallback for non-supporting UAs
it seems easier to fake <details> with script than <canvas>, and the latter has been done to some rough degree of quality
hsivonen: the <dt>/<dd> pattern even for containers that don't start with "d" is growing on me
it kind of makes sense to generalize them as a label/item pair for different contexts
i think i might add other <dx> elements to the parser even before we define such an element, btw
to make future introduction of such an element easier
especially if we start using <dt> everywhere
that seems wise
Faking <details> really isn't that hard, so there seems no reason not to use it now if it isn't broken at the parser level
Hixie, what would <dx> mean?
finds the problem with dt/dd is remembering which order they go in
Lachy: <ds> has been suggested for stage directions in <dialog>
(At least I can understand it as term/definition for <dl>, but that wouldn't help in any other contexts)
Lachy: dunno what other elements we might introduce, off-hand
Hixie: Instead of adding more stuff for <dialog>, <dialog> should go the way of <bb> and <datagrid>

I am more worried about the effect othermaciej mentioned (where implementors continually consider something low priority becuase IE doesn't support it) than the "authors might accidentially poison the well" argument
hsivonen: yeah that's possible too
hsivonen: but might still be useful to have some elements we can introduce later that already parse well
Hixie, it makes no sense to try and maintain the fiction that <dl> can't be used for dialogues
and thus keeping <dialog> is pointless
<dl> definitely can't be used for dialogs
jgraham_: it's not just "IE doesn't support it" but "no obvious way to patch around old (or slow-to-implement) browsers"
it makes absolutely no sense to use <dl> for dialogs
othermaciej: Yes, I was imprecise
Hixie, why?
IE doesn't support <video> but it's still totally valuable given the fallback capabilities
Lachy: does anyone actually use <dl> for marking up conversations?
I am not aware of examples
Lachy: it'd be like using <ol> for a postal address
off hand, I can only think of the example in the HTML4 spec that used it
Lachy: it superficially has a similar structure, but the semantic is no match at all
(it doesn't seem such a stretch to say that a conversation is a set of name-value groups where each name is the name and each value is the spoken text)
Lachy: if the HTML4 spec example is the only use, then it sounds like it would be a fiction to say it *can* be used for dialogs
"doesn't seem such a stretch" is how we know it's not the right solution
Hixie, dl is nothing but a general purpose assoication list. Pretending it has more semantics than that isn't helpful
you wouldn't need to say that if it wasn't a stretch
Lachy: a conversation is not an association list.
wonders if semantics are a problem or a solution here
othermaciej, in that case, I'd argue that basing the design of <dialog> on <dl> is bad design
Hixie: Not really. It is a "group of name-value data"
Hixie, it associates a speaker with what they said
Maybe someone should try to get actual data on how <dl> is used, rather than guessing
jgraham_, Lachy: i really couldn't disagree more
I wouldn't use an association list to represent a conversation in the languages that support them
or any other form of map
exactly
othermaciej: In programming languages they're unordered and usually have unique keys, which is completely unlike <dl>
Hixie: I'm not arguing that I like it being used that way or anything. I'm just arguing that it is impossible to rule out from the current spec text
my understanding of <dl> is that as with <ul>, order is not important; only the name/value mapping is important
but in a conversation, the order is primary, and labels are secondary
jgraham_: if you think a conversation is an "association list" or a "group of name-value data", then you need to get out more :-P
Many people use cite and blockquote for conversations anyway
it would be easier to make sense of a conversation with only statements in order and no speaker labels, than to make sense of it with randomly ordered statements listed per speaker
maybe we should just allow that
othermaciej: The spec says that order may be significant
othermaciej: actually, <dl>'s order can be important -- e.g. some of the <dl>s in the spec are like switch statements

othermaciej: That's just a matter of how you interpret the markup, which seems fundamentally different to association lists in programming languages where it's generally impossible to represent a meaningful order
but the opposite is true for an actual list of definitions
othermaciej, note that Hixie often uses <dl>'s where the order is important
Philip`: Lisp has association lists which are in fact ordered (but where relying on the order is considered poor form)
whether or not the order is relevant is entirely dependent on context. It can't be determined based on markup alone for a <dl>
I guess I am wrong about the philosophy of <dl> then
(By "generally" what I mean is "in Perl and Python, because I don't know how they work in other languages" :-) )

Hixie: specifically I think of the transcription of a conversation as an ordered set of key-value pairs where each key is the speaker (and possibly the timestamp) and each value is waht they said at that point
I believe the term "association list" comes from Lisp
I thought everything in Computer Science came from Lisp
Java also has an ordered hashtable type
javascript has ordered Objects (although the spec doesn't quite endorse this)
but name lookup is considered primary, and indexing secondary
I presume all these things still require keys to be unique
unlike <dl>
jgraham_: i don't think that even describes an irc log, let along any conversation
C++ has multimap with non-unique keys
jgraham_: actions, joins, parts, netsplits, etc.
but it doesn't have ordering
Hixie: Those aren't strictly part of the conversation
in C++ STL data structures, you would represent a conversation as a vector<> of pair<>s of strings, not any associative type
jgraham_: someone leaving the conversation is a pretty critical part of a conversation
likely also for any other programming language
thinks that this is part of the conversation too
Hixie: Arguably it is part of the context not part of the actual conversation.
it's part of whatever we're marking up
the speaker's name is not a key, it's a label
that is an important difference in data structure terms
It is possible that there is no demand for marking up context-free conversations but <dialog> doesn't work any better here than <dl>
a key is something by which you index
but you'd never index a conversation by speaker
othermaciej: Seems like you'd have to use a vector<> of pair<>s of strings to represent the content of any <dl> too
http://adactio.com/journal/1607/ is disturbing
so you'd be treating conversations the same as <dl>s
notes that the spec uses "name" not "key"
are <dl> terms intended to be unique?
jgraham_: <dialog> probably needs to go, yes
othermaciej: the spec doesn't say so yet, but it probably should
Hixie: I think that is for the best
Hixie: so now empirical data shows that the definitions for section, article and details suck
"I realise that it’s too small to be considered scientifically accurate" - not sure why he says that, since tens of data points are usually enough to be statistically significant
and curiously, hgroup seems to be the clearest of the lot
hsivonen: I would interpret the study as saying that the section, article and footer element names and/or definitions suck
othermaciej: fair enough
i don't think the bits he quoted are necessarily the best bits to quote, but yeah, section vs article needs help, certainly
someone mail me that url :-)
Clearly the definitions should define themselves in terms of the name of the element, e.g. "<section> represents a section", and then people will find it harder to mix them up
Hixie, at the end he says he'll post to the list
Hixie: mailed
given those quoted excerpts, I can see how people got <article> and <section> backwards
thanks
Philip`: yeah, that's kinda my point
The confusion between <article> and <section> seems to be the big takeaway from that
wouldn't be opposed against merging them
the biggest takeaway is to avoid the word "section" in the definition of <article>
good point - I wonder if the reversal would have been as common if it said "a part of a page"
instead of "a section of a page"
I think maybe it would be OK to postpone <article> to HTML6 once we have an idea of how people are using <section>
I bet it still would be though
since generally an <article> is-a <section>
see, i think <article> is far more important than either <figure> or <details> :-)
Maybe there needs to be a paragraph defining the difference between them.
and the definition for each needs to refer back to that
Hixie: I think you have the importance of article and figure backwards
i think you do :-)
I think the importance evaluation has to consider author desire to use the relevant element, and likelihood of using it correctly
wonders why Hixie thinks <article> is so important
it seems like both are higher for <figure> than <article>, regardless of their importance in the world of Platonic ideals
is changing <figure> and <details> to use <dt>/<dd>, and dropping <dialog>
woohoo!
wonders whether Tantek will be delighted or infuriated by that change
The way I see it is that <details> does something useful, and <article> is just a semantic way of saying <div class=article>, and it's fun to be anti-semantic
also, i hate you all. this is far more work than it's worth. :-P
hi Lachy!
hi
Lachy: may I prod you for an update on about: registration? any progress to report? should I push out the deadline?
i think <article>/<section> are important because there's a key difference between a blog post and a section of a blog post, or a blog comment and a section on a web page
(as an aside the sparklines on that post work rather nicely)
it's the difference between a chapter, and something that gets syndicated
jgraham_: I was also charmed by the sparklines
othermaciej, the deadline was this thursday, wasn't it?
jgraham_: I don't like how the sparklines ascribe significance to the arbitrary ordering of elements
Lachy: yes, it's this Thursday - just asking early
I actually planned to look at that stuff today. I have a lot of feedback I need to send to Joseph about the latest draft
It'd be less arbitrary if e.g. it ordered the values from highest to lowest in each sparkline
registering about: is more complex than I thought
Lachy: if you want to send an update by email, that's ok too, or I can ping you tomorrow, I was just assuming you probably wouldn't be at the telecon, so I wanted to make sure I'd have the data
I'll make sure you have some info before the telcon
finds a page that uses about:legacy-compat: http://xopus.com/
the potential flaw in the sparklines is that one could be really sharp and spikey while indicating 100% wrongness
Hixie: That difference already seems clear enough in practice, because the something that gets syndicated is the something in the RSS feed
<article>/<section> make sense in the case of a blog but get kind of confusing (with respect to each other and possibly with respect to <div>) in other contexts
othermaciej: yeah the right sparkline type for that data would be a series of red/black blocks (red for good answers, black for bad ones), or something like that
I guess dropping <article> makes the syndication-from-the-html thing harder
<article>/<section> also make clear sense in a forum, on a site like iGoogle, on anything with a clear body of content like an eBay page, etc.
Hixie: I agree that there is a difference and to me it is clear. I am concerned that it is not clear enough to everyone else
Hixie: I think recognizing messages as articles may be confusing for people actually.
I don't know how to use <article>/<section> in the context of apps, even though the spec says they can be used for that
jgraham_, from the uses of <article> that I've seen, people seem to be getting it right. The only issue has been the misuse of <section> as a wrapper within articles
I admit I am a bit puzzled by the apparent confusing over <article>/<section> in the context of documents
eBay is appy enough that I wouldn't be sure how to apply article/section
you can't use section to wrap sections inside articles?
webben: You can
If they are true subsections of the article
Okay. (Good.)
webben, yes, but people have been doing <article><header/><section/><footer/></article> where the section is nothing but a wrapper around the content
ah I see.
there are an UNGODLY number of <figure> examples in the spec
not surprising everyone wants to use it
i should put this many <menu> examples in
wonders in which religions god has an opinion on the HTML5 spec
jgraham_, that would be the god in Bible5
I'm pretty sure Bible5 has no God on the basis of lack of scientific evidince for His existance
isn't really sure about <menu> 'cause of hyatt's multiple "rants" about it
Shouldn't it equally have a God on the basis of lack of scientific evidence for His non-existence?
Pave the cowpaths, and all that
that doesn't scale
Philip`, no
and the cowpaths are contradictory
also, specs should be written based on reality, not on previous specs (like the christian bible, in this case)
whether or not there is evidence for God, a lot of people are using him
God is like xmlns
Better to just accept him and carry on
and make it a useless talisman in the process?
God is like violence. If he doesn't solve your problem, you're not using enough of him.
haha
annevk2: Sure, if it's enough to keep people happy
the problems only start when people try to force their talismans upon others and attack others for rejecting it.
if only all you Tagsoupists converted to the true path of Slashianity, we wouldn't have this problem
I'm sure we'd find something else to fight over instead
anyone around?
Perceptes: Maybe
laughs.
(It depends on whether you ask something that anyone feels like responding to)
I was hoping for some info on HTML 5 in IE. I ran into an issue I can't find any reference to on the web though it seems like it would be common.
What issue is that?

I'm using Remy Sharp's html5shiv script, but when I insert HTML5 elements into the page later with jQuery, the elements are not styled. If I look at the newly inserted HTML in IE 8's built in developer toolbar, I can see that it's not correctly nesting the elements - it sees the opening and closing tags of each HTML5 element as two separate tags.
I assume that's the http://code.google.com/p/html5shiv/source/browse/trunk/html5.js script?
that's the one.
What elements are you using it with?
The ones that are being inserted and not styled are article, header, section, and time.
the latter three being children of a single article element.
Do you make sure the script runs before loading jQuery?
Yes, it's loaded before all other JS and CSS files.
(That probably shouldn't matter, as long as the script runs before the parser reaches the new elements)
It only happens when injecting HTML5 elements with JS though, everything is styled correctly on initial page load, so I know the shiv script is working.
(Right but jQuery could be doing some clever caching or something so it seems worth checking)
Oh, okay, I missed that you said they were inserted later
might help if you show the page

I expect inserting elements with createElement/appendChild should work, and inserting with innerHTML probably ought to work too (though I'm not sure), but I have no idea how jQuery tries to insert elements
it's not on a live server

Perceptes: If you take jQuery out of the loop, does it work if you do something like <script>document.body.innerHTML = "<section style='background-color:green;'>I should be a child of the section</section>"</script>
lemme try
yeah, that works
so either jQuery is the culprit or just the way I'm doing it isn't right.
Perceptes: can you make a minimal testcase that fails?
I'll see what I can come up with
has had problems with things like jQuery selectors on new elements (<time> etc) in Opera
Philip`: Did you file a bug?
Actually, maybe the problem was with doing node.is('time')
so I replaced it with node[0].localName.toLowerCase() == 'time'
jgraham_: No, I just hacked around the problem so I could get on with what I wanted to be working on
Philip`: Do you mind filing a bug?
Oh, actually, node.is is jQuery selectors, I think
jgraham_: Filing a bug on whom?
Anyway, the answer is that I do mind a bit and probably wouldn't get around to doing it today
Opera I guess, if it works in other browsers. We can always file a bug on jQuery if they are doing something strage
Philip`: OK
Filing bugs takes far more effort than just complaining on IRC
Opera does casing different between unknown and known elements
isn't sure if the last Opera bug he filed was even CC'd to anyone who will actually be interested in looking at it and getting it fixed
